Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A new Telemedicine Platform using Incoherent Lensfree Cell Holography and Microscopy On a Chip

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0954482
Ozcan

The recent revolutionary progress in digital technologies together with novel image reconstruction algorithms and theories can fundamentally transform the way that we conduct cell microscopy, cytometry and medical diagnostics. With this vision, this proposal makes a systematic effort to highlight this timely opportunity to revolutionize cell microscopy by making it free of any lenses, lasers or other bulky optical components with a much simpler, compact and cost-effective imaging architecture especially suitable for telemedicine needs and requirements. Through incoherent lensfree cell holography & on-chip microscopy platform of this proposal (i.e., LUCAS), the PI proposes to compensate in the digital domain for the lack of complexity of optical components by recording individual phase & amplitude holograms of various cell types. These cell holograms also yield accurate reconstruction of microscopic images featuring sub-cellular resolution over a very large field of view (FOV) even at cell densities reaching up to ~0.4 Million cells/ìL. Merging cost-effective and compact LUCAS imagers with the state-of-the-art cell-phone technology will create numerous opportunities for telemedicine to improve health care especially in the developing world where medical facilities and infrastructure are extremely limited.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Field-Portable High-resolution Computational Microscopy and Cytometry Platform for Tele-medicine Applications

A team from UCLA's School of Engineering, funded by NSF Biophotonics Program, has created a field-portable microscopy and cytometry platform (see Figure 1) that weighs less than 150 grams with dimensions smaller than 17 × 6 × 5 cm, achieving sub-micron spatial resolution for imaging of biomedical specimen in color over a very large field-of-view. This field-portable and wide-field computational color microscope that is created in this project could be valuable for tele-medicine applications in resource poor settings or remote locations and can be used for high-throughput pathological investigation of specimen for e.g., early screening of various cancers (see Figure 2).

This developed technology permits orders of magnitude improvement in the cost, size and weight of the microscopic imaging and diagnostic instrument, making it highly suitable to be used by minimally trained medical personnel in third world countries or resource limited settings. This NSF funded project will lead to new biomedical instruments for various telemedicine applications, where mobile health-care providers will be able to enlarge the coverage span of hospitals through the use of light-weight and cost-effective measurement devices for mobile diagnostic analysis. The results of this project can also help us to replace automated scanning microscopes found in advanced laboratories or well-equipped hospitals for high-throughput micro- and nano-scale analysis with much simpler, less costly and easier to use lensfree holographic imagers that at the same time significantly improve the throughput.

In addition to providing transformative technical advances for optical microscopy, cytometry and telemedicine fields in general, this NSF funded project also established a complementary educational and outreach program which involved (1) public interviews and popular science articles in news media and internet; (2) undergraduate research opportunities in PI’s laboratory involving minority students; (3) an annual outreach program involving a tuition-free public charter school in a predominantly underrepresented neighborhood; (4) graduate student and postdoctoral training opportunities through organization of workshops, seminars and conferences; and (5) the development of a graduate level course on “Microscopy in Biophotonics”, which integrated ‘knowledge’ and ‘design’ aspects of engineering education into a single course. Furthermore, these research projects, seminars and open house visits have served undergrads and high school students (especially from minority groups) to interact with a cutting edge research environment, helping to increase their scientific curiosity and shaping their career goals in science and engineering.
